title: Iran's Protests and Internet Shutdown
summary: In Iran, many people are protesting, and the government has turned off the internet for over a week, so most of the 90 million people there cannot talk to the outside world. Human rights groups say more than 3,000 people have died because the government is cracking down hard on protesters. A top Iranian religious leader wants to execute prisoners. But President Trump thanked Iran for not executing hundreds of political prisoners. Reza Pahlavi, who used to be a prince of Iran and now lives outside the country, asked the United States to help by doing a military strike on specific targets in Iran to stop the violence. The article talks about how the U.S. promised help but hasn't done much, while Iran's government is being very harsh.

background_read: Iran is a country in the Middle East where people are protesting against the government. The government has turned off the internet to stop news from getting out. Human rights groups watch to see if people are treated fairly. The United States sometimes gets involved in other countries' problems to help people. Reza Pahlavi is a person who used to be in line to be king of Iran but now lives in another country and speaks out against the government.

WHAT: Iran shut off the internet, there is a crackdown with deaths, Reza Pahlavi asks for U.S. military help
WHY: To show the conflict in Iran and how the U.S. promised help but hasn't acted, while Iran's government is being violent
